book_title: Explanation of Ibn Farah al-Ishbili's Poem (Gharami Sahih)
text: Kafir (Disbeliever), every believer reads it, literate and non-literate" (1). This indicates that the believer perceives what others do not perceive. Especially in tribulations (Fitan), and the condition of the lying fabricator against Allah and His Messenger is unveiled to him. For the Dajjal is the greatest liar of Allah's creation; despite Allah conducting tremendous matters and earth-shaking miracles at his hands, such that whoever sees him is tested by him; Allah unveils them to the believer so he believes in their falsehood and invalidity. Whenever Faith strengthens in the heart; the unveiling of matters to it strengthens, and it knows their truths from their falsehoods. Whenever Faith weakens, the Unveiling (Kashf) weakens. That is like the strong lamp and the weak lamp in a dark house. For this reason, some of the Salaf said regarding His saying Almighty: {Light upon Light} [Al-Nur: 35], he said: It is the believer who speaks with wisdom matching the Truth, even if he did not hear a narration (Athar) regarding it. So if he hears a narration regarding it; it is Light upon Light. So the Faith in the heart of the believer matches the Light of the Quran. Thus, the inspiration of the heart is sometimes of the genus of speech, knowledge, and assumption; that this saying is a lie, and that this deed is invalid, or this is preponderant over this and more correct. In 'Al-Sahih' from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: "There were in the nations before you Muhaddathun (Inspired ones), so if there is anyone in my Ummah of them, then it is Umar" (2).
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (1131) from the hadith of Anas bin Malik; without his saying: 'Every believer reads it; literate...'. Narrated by Muslim (2934) from the hadith of Hudhayfah; except that he said: 'Writer and non-writer'. Instead of: 'Literate and non-literate'.
2. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (3689) from the hadith of Abu Hurayrah. Narrated by Muslim (2398) from the hadith of Aisha.

book_title: Explanation of Ibn Farah al-Ishbili's Poem (Gharami Sahih)
text: The Muhaddath: Is the one inspired (Mulham), addressed in his secret. Whatever Umar said regarding a thing "I think it is such and such"; it was as he thought. They used to consider that Sakinah (Tranquility/Divine Presence) speaks upon his heart and tongue. Furthermore: If cosmic matters can be unveiled to the believing servant due to the strength of his faith, as certainty and assumption, then religious matters—their unveiling to him is easier by priority, for he is in greater need of their unveiling. So the believer, evidences regarding things fall into his heart; he cannot express them in most cases, for not everyone can clarify the meanings established in his heart. If a liar speaks before a truthful person, he knows his lie from the content of his speech. The pride of modest Faith enters upon him preventing him from clarification, but he himself has taken his caution against him. Perhaps he hints or declares it out of fear of Allah, and compassion for Allah's creation; so they may beware of his narration or acting upon it. Many of the People of Faith and Unveiling, Allah casts into their hearts that this food is Haram, or that this man is a Kafir, or Fasiq, or Dayyuth, or Lutiy (sodomite), or Khammar (drunkard), or singer, or liar, without apparent evidence, rather by what Allah casts into his heart. Likewise the reverse, He casts into his heart a plea/argument (1) for a person, and that he is from the Awliya (Allies) of Allah, and that this man is righteous, this food is Halal, and this saying is Truth. This and its likes should not be considered unlikely regarding the righteous believing Awliya of Allah. The story of Al-Khidr with Musa is from this chapter, and that Al-Khidr knew these specific (2) states by what Allah informed him of. This is a wide chapter, expanding on it would take long, we have alerted in it to noble points that will inform you of what is behind them (3).
foot_note:
1. 'Plea/Argument' (Hujjah): In 'Majmu' al-Fatawa': 'Mahabbah' (Love).
2. 'The specific' (Al-Mu'ayyanah): Thus in the original and (K), perhaps the correct word is: 'Al-Mughayyabah' (The Unseen/Hidden).
3. 'Majmu' al-Fatawa' (20/42-48).

book_title: Explanation of Ibn Farah al-Ishbili's Poem (Gharami Sahih)
text: The Intent: The saying of the Author, the Explainer: That the Fabricated Hadith is known to be fabricated either by the confession of its fabricator, or the poorness of its wording, or otherwise. We have indicated in what we wrote previously that the People of Faith, Taqwa, Truthfulness, and Sincerity; they have insights, unveilings, physiognomies (Firasat), and inspirations which Allah casts into their hearts, by which they know the truthfulness of the truthful, the lying of the liar, the fabrication of the fabricators, and the authentic reports from the false ones. Abu Sulaiman al-Darani used to call Ahmad bin Asim al-Antaqi (1): The Spy of the Hearts; due to the sharpness of his physiognomy. So upon you, O my brother, is Truthfulness, and beware of Lying, for it is separate from Faith. Allah Glory be to Him knows best the correct view, and to Him is the return and destination. Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds. Let us return now to the speech we were concerned with regarding the knowledge of Hadith.
foot_note: 1. He is the Imam, the Example, the Preacher, the Ascetic. He was of the class of Al-Harith al-Muhasibi and Bishr al-Hafi. Ibn Kathir said: He has beautiful speech on Asceticism and the transactions of the heart. Al-Dhahabi said: Perhaps he remained until around two hundred and thirty. See: 'Al-Hilyah' (9/280), 'Al-Siyar' (10/487) and (11/409), and 'Al-Bidaya wa Al-Nihaya' (14/357) Ed/ Hajar.
